column1: ap 11:30|"half-past eleven"|"It was a warm
column2: bright day at the end of August. The interview with the elder had been fixed for half-past eleven
column3: immediately after late mass. Our visitors did not take part in the service
column4: but arrived just as it was over. First an elegant open carriage
column5: drawn by two valuable horses
column6: drove up with Miüsov and a distant relative of his
column7: a young man of twenty
column8: called Pyotr Fomitch Kalganov. This young man was preparing to enter the university. Miüsov
column9: with whom he was staying for the time
column10: was trying to persuade him to go abroad to the university of Zurich or Jena. The young man was still undecided. He was thoughtful and absent-minded. He was nice-looking
column11: strongly built
column12: and rather tall. There was a strange fixity in his gaze at times. Like all very absent-minded people he would sometimes stare at a person without seeing him. He was silent and rather awkward
column13: but sometimes
column14: when he was alone with any one
column15: he became talkative and effusive
column16: and would laugh at anything or nothing. But his animation vanished as quickly as it appeared. He was always well and even elaborately dressed; he had already some independent fortune and expectations of much more. He was a friend of Alyosha's."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 01:00|"one o'clock"|"""The Father Superior invites all of you gentlemen to dine with him after your visit to the hermitage. At one o'clock
column2: not later. And you also
column3: he added
column4: addressing Maximov."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 00:00|twelve|"A cheap little clock on the wall struck twelve hurriedly
column2: and served to begin the conversation."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 00:30|"half-past twelve"|"The elder's absence from his cell had lasted for about twenty-five minutes. It was more than half-past twelve
column2: but Dmitri
column3: on whose account they had all met there
column4: had still not appeared. But he seemed almost to be forgotten
column5: and when the elder entered the cell again
column6: he found his guests engaged in eager conversation. Ivan and the two monks took the leading share in it. Miüsov
column7: too
column8: was trying to take a part
column9: and apparently very eagerly
column10: in the conversation. But he was unsuccessful in this also. He was evidently in the background
column11: and his remarks were treated with neglect
column12: which increased his irritability. He had had intellectual encounters with Ivan before and he could not endure a certain carelessness Ivan showed him."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: 16:00|"four o'clock in the afternoon"|"""No one but you and one 'jade' I have fallen in love with
column2: to my ruin. But being in love doesn't mean loving. You may be in love with a woman and yet hate her. Remember that! I can talk about it gayly still. Sit down here by the table and I'll sit beside you and look at you
column3: and go on talking. You shall keep quiet and I'll go on talking
column4: for the time has come. But on reflection
column5: you know
column6: I'd better speak quietly
column7: for here--here--you can never tell what ears are listening. I will explain everything; as they say
column8: 'the story will be continued.' Why have I been longing for you? Why have I been thirsting for you all these days
column9: and just now? (It's five days since I've cast anchor here.) Because it's only to you I can tell everything; because I must
column10: because I need you
column11: because to-morrow I shall fly from the clouds
column12: because to-morrow life is ending and beginning. Have you ever felt
column13: have you ever dreamt of falling down a precipice into a pit? That's just how I'm falling
column14: but not in a dream. And I'm not afraid
column15: and don't you be afraid. At least
column16: I am afraid
column17: but I enjoy it. It's not enjoyment though
column19: whatever it is! A strong spirit
column21: a womanish spirit--whatever it is! Let us praise nature: you see what sunshine
column24: it's still summer; four o'clock in the afternoon and the stillness! Where were you going?"""|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: 00:00|midnight|"""Yes. I know it will take some time. You can't go at him point blank. He's drunk now. I'll wait three hours--four
column2: five
column3: six
column4: seven. Only remember you must go to Katerina Ivanovna to-day
column5: if it has to be at midnight
column6: _with the money or without the money_
column7: and say
column8: 'He sends his compliments to you.' I want you to say that verse to her: 'He sends his compliments to you.' """|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 03:00|three|"He did in fact find his father still at table. Though there was a dining-room in the house
column2: the table was laid as usual in the drawing-room
column3: which was the largest room
column4: and furnished with old-fashioned ostentation. The furniture was white and very old
column5: upholstered in old
column6: red
column7: silky material. In the spaces between the windows there were mirrors in elaborate white and gilt frames
column8: of old-fashioned carving. On the walls
column9: covered with white paper
column10: which was torn in many places
column11: there hung two large portraits--one of some prince who had been governor of the district thirty years before
column12: and the other of some bishop
column13: also long since dead. In the corner opposite the door there were several ikons
column14: before which a lamp was lighted at nightfall ... not so much for devotional purposes as to light the room. Fyodor Pavlovitch used to go to bed very late
column15: at three or four o'clock in the morning
column16: and would wander about the room at night or sit in an arm-chair
column17: thinking. This had become a habit with him. He often slept quite alone in the house
column18: sending his servants to the lodge; but usually Smerdyakov remained
column19: sleeping on a bench in the hall."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 07:00|"seven o'clock"|"It was by now seven o'clock
column2: and it was getting dark as Alyosha entered the very spacious and convenient house in the High Street occupied by Katerina Ivanovna. Alyosha knew that she lived with two aunts. One of them
column3: a woman of little education
column4: was that aunt of her half-sister Agafya Ivanovna who had looked after her in her father's house when she came from boarding-school. The other aunt was a Moscow lady of style and consequence
column5: though in straitened circumstances. It was said that they both gave way in everything to Katerina Ivanovna
column6: and that she only kept them with her as chaperons. Katerina Ivanovna herself gave way to no one but her benefactress
column7: the general's widow
column8: who had been kept by illness in Moscow
column9: and to whom she was obliged to write twice a week a full account of all her doings."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ~ 16:30|"evening prayer"|"Alyosha returned to the other room
column2: where Father Zossima had received his guests in the morning. Taking off his boots
column3: he lay down on the hard
column4: narrow
column5: leathern sofa
column6: which he had long used as a bed
column7: bringing nothing but a pillow. The mattress
column8: about which his father had shouted to him that morning
column9: he had long forgotten to lie on. He took off his cassock
column10: which he used as a covering. But before going to bed
column11: he fell on his knees and prayed a long time. In his fervent prayer he did not beseech God to lighten his darkness but only thirsted for the joyous emotion
column12: which always visited his soul after the praise and adoration
column13: of which his evening prayer usually consisted. That joy always brought him light untroubled sleep. As he was praying
column14: he suddenly felt in his pocket the little pink note the servant had handed him as he left Katerina Ivanovna's. He was disturbed
column15: but finished his prayer. Then
column16: after some hesitation
column17: he opened the envelope. In it was a letter to him
column19: the young daughter of Madame Hohlakov
column20: who had laughed at him before the elder in the morning."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 03:00|"three o'clock"|"""Our dietary is according to the ancient conventual rules. During Lent there are no meals provided for Monday
column2: Wednesday
column3: and Friday. For Tuesday and Thursday we have white bread
column4: stewed fruit with honey
column5: wild berries
column6: or salt cabbage and wholemeal stirabout. On Saturday white cabbage soup
column7: noodles with peas
column8: kasha
column9: all with hemp oil. On weekdays we have dried fish and kasha with the cabbage soup. From Monday till Saturday evening
column10: six whole days in Holy Week
column11: nothing is cooked
column12: and we have only bread and water
column13: and that sparingly; if possible not taking food every day
column14: just the same as is ordered for first week in Lent. On Good Friday nothing is eaten. In the same way on the Saturday we have to fast till three o'clock
column15: and then take a little bread and water and drink a single cup of wine. On Holy Thursday we drink wine and have something cooked without oil or not cooked at all
column16: inasmuch as the Laodicean council lays down for Holy Thursday: 'It is unseemly by remitting the fast on the Holy Thursday to dishonor the whole of Lent!' This is how we keep the fast. But what is that compared with you
column17: holy Father
column22: you take nothing but bread and water
column23: and what we should eat in two days lasts you full seven. It's truly marvelous--your great abstinence."""|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap < 03:00|"nearly three o'clock"|"He had no time to lose indeed. Even while he was saying good-by to Lise
column2: the thought had struck him that he must attempt some stratagem to find his brother Dmitri
column3: who was evidently keeping out of his way. It was getting late
column4: nearly three o'clock. Alyosha's whole soul turned to the monastery
column5: to his dying saint
column6: but the necessity of seeing Dmitri outweighed everything. The conviction that a great inevitable catastrophe was about to happen grew stronger in Alyosha's mind with every hour. What that catastrophe was
column7: and what he would say at that moment to his brother
column8: he could perhaps not have said definitely. ""Even if my benefactor must die without me
column9: anyway I won't have to reproach myself all my life with the thought that I might have saved something and did not
column10: but passed by and hastened home. If I do as I intend
column11: I shall be following his great precept."""|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 08:00|"eight o'clock"|"""Well
column2: the only thing I can tell you is this
column3: said Smerdyakov
column4: as though thinking better of it; ""I am here as an old friend and neighbor
column5: and it would be odd if I didn't come. On the other hand
column6: Ivan Fyodorovitch sent me first thing this morning to your brother's lodging in Lake Street
column7: without a letter
column8: but with a message to Dmitri Fyodorovitch to go to dine with him at the restaurant here
column9: in the market-place. I went
column10: but didn't find Dmitri Fyodorovitch at home
column11: though it was eight o'clock. 'He's been here
column12: but he is quite gone
column13: ' those were the very words of his landlady. It's as though there was an understanding between them. Perhaps at this moment he is in the restaurant with Ivan Fyodorovitch
column14: for Ivan Fyodorovitch has not been home to dinner and Fyodor Pavlovitch dined alone an hour ago
column15: and is gone to lie down. But I beg you most particularly not to speak of me and of what I have told you
column16: for he'd kill me for nothing at all."""|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: 00:00|midnight|"Smerdyakov went on. ""I am speaking of your parent and your brother Dmitri Fyodorovitch. Here Fyodor Pavlovitch will get up directly and begin worrying me every minute
column2: 'Has she come? Why hasn't she come?' and so on up till midnight and even after midnight. And if Agrafena Alexandrovna doesn't come (for very likely she does not mean to come at all) then he will be at me again to-morrow morning
column3: 'Why hasn't she come? When will she come?'--as though I were to blame for it. On the other side it's no better. As soon as it gets dark
column4: or even before
column5: your brother will appear with his gun in his hands: 'Look out
column6: you rogue
column7: you soup-maker. If you miss her and don't let me know she's been--I'll kill you before any one.' When the night's over
column8: in the morning
column9: he
column10: too
column11: like Fyodor Pavlovitch
column12: begins worrying me to death. 'Why hasn't she come? Will she come soon?' And he
column13: too
column14: thinks me to blame because his lady hasn't come. And every day and every hour they get angrier and angrier
column15: so that I sometimes think I shall kill myself in a fright. I can't depend upon them
column16: sir."""|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column16: sir."""|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: 00:00|midnight|"""that I have a secret with Fyodor Pavlovitch in this business. As you know yourself (if only you do know it) he has for several days past locked himself in as soon as night or even evening comes on. Of late you've been going upstairs to your room early every evening
column2: and yesterday you did not come down at all
column3: and so perhaps you don't know how carefully he has begun to lock himself in at night
column4: and even if Grigory Vassilyevitch comes to the door he won't open to him till he hears his voice. But Grigory Vassilyevitch does not come
column5: because I wait upon him alone in his room now. That's the arrangement he made himself ever since this to-do with Agrafena Alexandrovna began. But at night
column6: by his orders
column7: I go away to the lodge so that I don't get to sleep till midnight
column8: but am on the watch
column9: getting up and walking about the yard
column10: waiting for Agrafena Alexandrovna to come. For the last few days he's been perfectly frantic expecting her. What he argues is
column11: she is afraid of him
column12: Dmitri Fyodorovitch (Mitya
column13: as he calls him)
column14: 'and so
column15: ' says he
column16: 'she'll come the back-way
column17: late at night
column18: to me. You look out for her
column20: 'till midnight and later; and if she does come
column21: you run up and knock at my door or at the window from the garden. Knock at first twice
column23: and then three times more quickly
column26: 'I shall understand at once that she has come
column27: and will open the door to you quietly.' Another signal he gave me in case anything unexpected happens. At first
column31: another much louder. Then he will understand that something has happened suddenly and that I must see him
column32: and he will open to me so that I can go and speak to him. That's all in case Agrafena Alexandrovna can't come herself
column36: so I must let him know he is near. His honor is awfully afraid of Dmitri Fyodorovitch
column37: so that even if Agrafena Alexandrovna had come and were locked in with him
column38: and Dmitri Fyodorovitch were to turn up anywhere near at the time
column39: I should be bound to let him know at once
column40: knocking three times. So that the first signal of five knocks means Agrafena Alexandrovna has come
column41: while the second signal of three knocks means"|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 02:00|"two o'clock"|"It was very late
column2: but Ivan was still awake and reflecting. He sat up late that night
column3: till two o'clock. But we will not give an account of his thoughts
column4: and this is not the place to look into that soul--its turn will come. And even if one tried
column5: it would be very hard to give an account of them
column6: for there were no thoughts in his brain
column7: but something very vague
column8: and
column9: above all
column10: intense excitement. He felt himself that he had lost his bearings. He was fretted
column11: too
column12: by all sorts of strange and almost surprising desires; for instance
column13: after midnight he suddenly had an intense irresistible inclination to go down
column14: open the door
column15: go to the lodge and beat Smerdyakov. But if he had been asked why
column16: he could not have given any exact reason
column17: except perhaps that he loathed the valet as one who had insulted him more gravely than any one in the world. On the other hand
column18: he was more than once that night overcome by a sort of inexplicable humiliating terror
column19: which he felt positively paralyzed his physical powers. His head ached and he was giddy. A feeling of hatred was rankling in his heart
column20: as though he meant to avenge himself on some one. He even hated Alyosha
column21: recalling the conversation he had just had with him. At moments he hated himself intensely. Of Katerina Ivanovna he almost forgot to think
column22: and wondered greatly at this afterwards
column23: especially as he remembered perfectly that when he had protested so valiantly to Katerina Ivanovna that he would go away next day to Moscow
column24: something had whispered in his heart
column27: and it won't be so easy to tear yourself away as you are boasting now."""|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap ~ 02:00|"About two o'clock"|"About two o'clock when everything was quiet
column2: and even Fyodor Pavlovitch had gone to bed
column3: Ivan had got into bed
column4: firmly resolved to fall asleep at once
column5: as he felt fearfully exhausted. And he did fall asleep at once
column6: and slept soundly without dreams
column7: but waked early
column8: at seven o'clock
column9: when it was broad daylight. Opening his eyes
column10: he was surprised to feel himself extraordinarily vigorous. He jumped up at once and dressed quickly; then dragged out his trunk and began packing immediately. His linen had come back from the laundress the previous morning. Ivan positively smiled at the thought that everything was helping his sudden departure. And his departure certainly was sudden. Though Ivan had said the day before (to Katerina Ivanovna
column11: Alyosha
column12: and Smerdyakov) that he was leaving next day
column13: yet he remembered that he had no thought of departure when he went to bed
column14: or
column15: at least
column16: had not dreamed that his first act in the morning would be to pack his trunk. At last his trunk and bag were ready. It was about nine o'clock when Marfa Ignatyevna came in with her usual inquiry
column17: ""Where will your honor take your tea
column18: in your own room or downstairs?"" He looked almost cheerful
column21: something hurried and scattered. Greeting his father affably
column22: and even inquiring specially after his health
column23: though he did not wait to hear his answer to the end
column24: he announced that he was starting off in an hour to return to Moscow for good
column25: and begged him to send for the horses. His father heard this announcement with no sign of surprise
column26: and forgot in an unmannerly way to show regret at losing him. Instead of doing so
column27: he flew into a great flutter at the recollection of some important business of his own."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 07:00|"seven o'clock"|"""I'm sorry
column2: I can't. It's eighty versts to the railway and the train starts for Moscow at seven o'clock to-night. I can only just catch it."""|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 07:00|"seven o'clock"|"At seven o'clock Ivan got into the train and set off to Moscow ""Away with the past. I've done with the old world for ever
column2: and may I have no news
column3: no echo
column4: from it. To a new life
column5: new places and no looking back!"" But instead of delight his soul was filled with such gloom
column6: and his heart ached with such anguish
column7: as he had never known in his life before. He was thinking all the night. The train flew on
column8: and only at daybreak
column9: when he was approaching Moscow
column10: he suddenly roused himself from his meditation."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 07:00|"seven o'clock"|"It was the end of June
column2: and our meeting was to take place at seven o'clock the next day on the outskirts of the town--and then something happened that in very truth was the turning-point of my life. In the evening
column3: returning home in a savage and brutal humor
column4: I flew into a rage with my orderly Afanasy
column5: and gave him two blows in the face with all my might
column6: so that it was covered with blood. He had not long been in my service and I had struck him before
column7: but never with such ferocious cruelty. And
column8: believe me
column9: though it's forty years ago
column10: I recall it now with shame and pain. I went to bed and slept for about three hours; when I waked up the day was breaking. I got up--I did not want to sleep any more--I went to the window--opened it
column11: it looked out upon the garden; I saw the sun rising; it was warm and beautiful
column12: the birds were singing."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ~ 00:00|"about midnight"|"""Good God
column2: I thought
column3: ""what has he gone to face!"" I fell on my knees before the ikon and wept for him before the Holy Mother of God
column4: our swift defender and helper. I was half an hour praying in tears
column5: and it was late
column6: about midnight. Suddenly I saw the door open and he came in again. I was surprised."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: 00:00|midnight|"""Do you remember how I came back to you that second time
column2: at midnight? I told you to remember it. You know what I came back for? I came to kill you!"""|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: 15:00|"three o'clock in the afternoon"|"Meanwhile the time was passing; the monastery services and the requiems for the dead followed in their due course. Father Païssy again took Father Iosif's place by the coffin and began reading the Gospel. But before three o'clock in the afternoon that something took place to which I alluded at the end of the last book
column2: something so unexpected by all of us and so contrary to the general hope
column3: that
column4: I repeat
column5: this trivial incident has been minutely remembered to this day in our town and all the surrounding neighborhood. I may add here
column6: for myself personally
column7: that I feel it almost repulsive to recall that event which caused such frivolous agitation and was such a stumbling-block to many
column8: though in reality it was the most natural and trivial matter. I should
column9: of course
column10: have omitted all mention of it in my story
column11: if it had not exerted a very strong influence on the heart and soul of the chief
column12: though future
column13: hero of my story
column14: Alyosha
column15: forming a crisis and turning-point in his spiritual development
column16: giving a shock to his intellect
column17: which finally strengthened it for the rest of his life and gave it a definite aim."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: > 12:00|"after midday"|"And
column2: behold
column3: soon after midday there were signs of something
column4: at first only observed in silence by those who came in and out and were evidently each afraid to communicate the thought in his mind. But by three o'clock those signs had become so clear and unmistakable
column5: that the news swiftly reached all the monks and visitors in the hermitage
column6: promptly penetrated to the monastery
column7: throwing all the monks into amazement
column8: and finally
column9: in the shortest possible time
column10: spread to the town
column11: exciting every one in it
column12: believers and unbelievers alike. The unbelievers rejoiced
column13: and as for the believers some of them rejoiced even more than the unbelievers
column14: for ""men love the downfall and disgrace of the righteous
column15: as the deceased elder had said in one of his exhortations."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 03:00|"three o'clock"|"The fact is that a smell of decomposition began to come from the coffin
column2: growing gradually more marked
column3: and by three o'clock it was quite unmistakable. In all the past history of our monastery
column4: no such scandal could be recalled
column5: and in no other circumstances could such a scandal have been possible
column6: as showed itself in unseemly disorder immediately after this discovery among the very monks themselves. Afterwards
column7: even many years afterwards
column8: some sensible monks were amazed and horrified
column9: when they recalled that day
column10: that the scandal could have reached such proportions. For in the past
column11: monks of very holy life had died
column12: God-fearing old men
column13: whose saintliness was acknowledged by all
column14: yet from their humble coffins
column15: too
column16: the breath of corruption had come
column17: naturally
column19: but that had caused no scandal nor even the slightest excitement. Of course there had been
column21: saints in the monastery whose memory was carefully preserved and whose relics
column23: showed no signs of corruption. This fact was regarded by the monks as touching and mysterious
column24: and the tradition of it was cherished as something blessed and miraculous
column27: of still greater glory from their tombs in the future."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap > 03:00|"After three o'clock"|"Visitors from outside
column2: particularly of the educated class
column3: soon went into the cell
column4: too
column5: with the same spying intent. Of the peasantry few went into the cell
column6: though there were crowds of them at the gates of the hermitage. After three o'clock the rush of worldly visitors was greatly increased and this was no doubt owing to the shocking news. People were attracted who would not otherwise have come on that day and had not intended to come
column7: and among them were some personages of high standing. But external decorum was still preserved and Father Païssy
column8: with a stern face
column9: continued firmly and distinctly reading aloud the Gospel
column10: apparently not noticing what was taking place around him
column11: though he had
column12: in fact
column13: observed something unusual long before. But at last the murmurs
column14: first subdued but gradually louder and more confident
column15: reached even him. ""It shows God's judgment is not as man's
column16: Father Païssy heard suddenly. The first to give utterance to this sentiment was a layman
column17: an elderly official from the town
column18: known to be a man of great piety. But he only repeated aloud what the monks had long been whispering. They had long before formulated this damning conclusion
column19: and the worst of it was that a sort of triumphant satisfaction at that conclusion became more and more apparent every moment. Soon they began to lay aside even external decorum and almost seemed to feel they had a sort of right to discard it."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: 00:00|midnight|"""I tell you
column2: I am expecting news

column4: so I don't want Mitya at all. And he didn't believe
column5: I feel he didn't
column6: that I should stay at Kuzma Kuzmitch's. He must be in his ambush now
column7: behind Fyodor Pavlovitch's
column8: in the garden
column9: watching for me. And if he's there

column12: Mitya escorted me there. I told him I should stay there till midnight
column13: and I asked him to be sure to come at midnight to fetch me home. He went away and I sat ten minutes with Kuzma Kuzmitch and came back here again. Ugh
column14: I was afraid
column15: I ran for fear of meeting him."""|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 09:00|"nine o'clock"|"It was very late
column2: according to the monastery ideas
column3: when Alyosha returned to the hermitage; the door-keeper let him in by a special entrance. It had struck nine o'clock--the hour of rest and repose after a day of such agitation for all. Alyosha timidly opened the door and went into the elder's cell where his coffin was now standing. There was no one in the cell but Father Païssy
column4: reading the Gospel in solitude over the coffin
column5: and the young novice Porfiry
column6: who
column7: exhausted by the previous night's conversation and the disturbing incidents of the day
column8: was sleeping the deep sound sleep of youth on the floor of the other room. Though Father Païssy heard Alyosha come in
column9: he did not even look in his direction. Alyosha turned to the right from the door to the corner
column10: fell on his knees and began to pray."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 10:00|"ten o'clock"|"After his conversation with Alyosha
column2: at the cross-roads
column3: he hardly slept all night
column4: and at ten o'clock next morning
column5: he was at the house of Samsonov and telling the servant to announce him. It was a very large and gloomy old house of two stories
column6: with a lodge and outhouses. In the lower story lived Samsonov's two married sons with their families
column7: his old sister
column8: and his unmarried daughter. In the lodge lived two of his clerks
column9: one of whom also had a large family. Both the lodge and the lower story were overcrowded
column10: but the old man kept the upper floor to himself
column11: and would not even let the daughter live there with him
column12: though she waited upon him
column13: and in spite of her asthma was obliged at certain fixed hours
column14: and at any time he might call her
column15: to run upstairs to him from below."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: 12:00|midday|"""And I didn't expect that
column2: cried Mitya
column3: ecstatically. (He was still in a state of ecstasy.) He seized his six roubles and ran home. At home he borrowed three roubles from the people of the house
column4: who loved him so much that they were pleased to give it him
column5: though it was all they had. Mitya in his excitement told them on the spot that his fate would be decided that day
column6: and he described
column7: in desperate haste
column8: the whole scheme he had put before Samsonov
column9: the latter's decision
column10: his own hopes for the future
column11: and so on. These people had been told many of their lodger's secrets before
column12: and so looked upon him as a gentleman who was not at all proud
column13: and almost one of themselves. Having thus collected nine roubles Mitya sent for posting-horses to take him to the Volovya station. This was how the fact came to be remembered and established that ""at midday
column14: on the day before the event
column15: Mitya had not a farthing
column16: and that he had sold his watch to get money and had borrowed three roubles from his landlord
column17: all in the presence of witnesses."""|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap ~ 09:00|"about nine o'clock"|"It was dreadfully late when he waked. It was somewhere about nine o'clock. The sun was shining brightly in the two little windows of the hut. The curly-headed peasant was sitting on the bench and had his coat on. He had another samovar and another bottle in front of him. Yesterday's bottle had already been finished
column2: and the new one was more than half empty. Mitya jumped up and saw at once that the cursed peasant was drunk again
column3: hopelessly and incurably. He stared at him for a moment with wide opened eyes. The peasant was silently and slyly watching him
column4: with insulting composure
column5: and even a sort of contemptuous condescension
column6: so Mitya fancied. He rushed up to him."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 00:00|"twelve o'clock"|"This was the visit of Mitya of which Grushenka had spoken to Rakitin with such horror. She was just then expecting the ""message
column2: and was much relieved that Mitya had not been to see her that day or the day before. She hoped that ""please God he won't come till I'm gone away
column3: and he suddenly burst in on her. The rest we know already. To get him off her hands she suggested at once that he should walk with her to Samsonov's
column4: where she said she absolutely must go ""to settle his accounts
column5: and when Mitya accompanied her at once
column6: she said good-by to him at the gate
column7: making him promise to come at twelve o'clock to take her home again. Mitya
column8: too
column9: was delighted at this arrangement. If she was sitting at Samsonov's she could not be going to Fyodor Pavlovitch's
column10: ""if only she's not lying
column11: he added at once. But he thought she was not lying from what he saw."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 11:00|eleven|"""Then he must have driven through Volovya before me
column2: thought Dmitri
column3: but he was terribly distressed about Smerdyakov. ""What will happen now? Who'll keep watch for me? Who'll bring me word?"" he thought. He began greedily questioning the women whether they had seen anything the evening before. They quite understood what he was trying to find out
column4: and completely reassured him. No one had been there. Ivan Fyodorovitch had been there the night; everything had been perfectly as usual. Mitya grew thoughtful. He would certainly have to keep watch to-day
column5: but where? Here or at Samsonov's gate? He decided that he must be on the look out both here and there
column6: and meanwhile ... meanwhile.... The difficulty was that he had to carry out the new plan that he had made on the journey back. He was sure of its success
column7: but he must not delay acting upon it. Mitya resolved to sacrifice an hour to it: ""In an hour I shall know everything
column8: I shall settle everything
column9: and then
column10: then
column11: first of all to Samsonov's. I'll inquire whether Grushenka's there and instantly be back here again
column12: stay till eleven
column13: and then to Samsonov's again to bring her home."" This was what he decided."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 07:30|"half-past seven"|"As for his ""plan"" it was just the same as before; it consisted of the offer of his rights to Tchermashnya--but not with a commercial object
column2: as it had been with Samsonov
column3: not trying to allure the lady with the possibility of making a profit of six or seven thousand--but simply as a security for the debt. As he worked out this new idea
column4: Mitya was enchanted with it
column5: but so it always was with him in all his undertakings
column6: in all his sudden decisions. He gave himself up to every new idea with passionate enthusiasm. Yet
column7: when he mounted the steps of Madame Hohlakov's house he felt a shiver of fear run down his spine. At that moment he saw fully
column8: as a mathematical certainty
column9: that this was his last hope
column10: that if this broke down
column11: nothing else was left him in the world
column12: but to ""rob and murder some one for the three thousand."" It was half-past seven when he rang at the bell."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 08:30|"half-past eight"|"Just ten minutes later Dmitri went in to Pyotr Ilyitch Perhotin

column4: and had just put his coat on again to go to the ""Metropolis"" to play billiards. Mitya caught him coming out."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

00:00|midnight|"The most direct and the easiest thing for him to do would have been to go straight to Fyodor Pavlovitch's

column3: and if so

column9: and what if

column13: how a stranger

column15: had broken in upon him at midnight to ask if any one had killed him. It would make a scandal. And scandal was what Pyotr Ilyitch dreaded more than anything in the world."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column7: sometimes

column10: growing more and more painful and driving him on
column11: against his will. Yet he kept cursing himself

column1: ap ~ 08:00|"about eight o'clock"|"But Marfa continued screaming
column2: and seeing that her master's window was open and that there was a candle alight in the window
column3: she ran there and began calling Fyodor Pavlovitch. But peeping in at the window
column4: she saw a fearful sight. Her master was lying on his back
column5: motionless
column6: on the floor. His light-colored dressing-gown and white shirt were soaked with blood. The candle on the table brightly lighted up the blood and the motionless dead face of Fyodor Pavlovitch. Terror-stricken

column8: ran out of the garden
column9: drew the bolt of the big gate and ran headlong by the back way to the neighbor
column10: Marya Kondratyevna. Both mother and daughter were asleep
column11: but they waked up at Marfa's desperate and persistent screaming and knocking at the shutter. Marfa
column12: shrieking and screaming incoherently
column13: managed to tell them the main fact
column14: and to beg for assistance. It happened that Foma had come back from his wanderings and was staying the night with them. They got him up immediately and all three ran to the scene of the crime. On the way
column15: Marya Kondratyevna remembered that at about eight o'clock she heard a dreadful scream from their garden
column16: and this was no doubt Grigory's scream
column17: ""Parricide!"" uttered when he caught hold of Mitya's leg."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column11: almost at sunrise

column4: Pyotr Ilyitch Perhotin."""|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: 00:00|midnight|"Mitya let them write it without protest. At last he reached the point in his story when he learned that Grushenka had deceived him and had returned from Samsonov's as soon as he left her there

column1: 05:00|"five o'clock in the morning"|"""Yes
column2: a grand feast the night before. Damn it all

column4: beyond the village
column5: and I'd planned to do it at five o'clock in the morning. And I had a note in my pocket already. I wrote it at Perhotin's when I loaded my pistols. Here's the letter. Read it! It's not for you I tell it
column6: he added contemptuously. He took it from his waistcoat pocket and flung it on the table. The lawyers read it with curiosity
column7: and
column8: as is usual

column2: I should have galloped here just the same
column3: and shot myself at five o'clock
column4: and you wouldn't have been in time to do anything. If it hadn't been for what's happened to my father
column5: you would have known nothing about it
column6: and wouldn't have come here. Oh
column7: it's the devil's doing. It was the devil murdered father
column8: it was through the devil that you found it out so soon. How did you manage to get here so quick? It's marvelous
column9: a dream!"""|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column3: when by your own confession
column4: at five o'clock the same day you--"""|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column2: ""when at five o'clock on the same day
column3: from your own confession--"""|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 05:00|"five o'clock"|"""Damn five o'clock on the same day and my own confession! That's nothing to do with it now! That money was my own
column2: my own
column3: that is
column4: stolen by me ... not mine
column5: I mean
column6: but stolen by me
column7: and it was fifteen hundred roubles
column8: and I had it on me all the time
column9: all the time ..."""|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: 05:00|"five o'clock this morning"|"""Why? It's absurd to ask. Because I had condemned myself to die at five o'clock this morning
column2: here
column3: at dawn. I thought it made no difference whether I died a thief or a man of honor. But I see it's not so
column4: it turns out that it does make a difference. Believe me
column5: gentlemen
column6: what has tortured me most during this night has not been the thought that I'd killed the old servant
column7: and that I was in danger of Siberia just when my love was being rewarded
column8: and Heaven was open to me again. Oh
column9: that did torture me
column10: but not in the same way: not so much as the damned consciousness that I had torn that damned money off my breast at last and spent it
column11: and had become a downright thief! Oh
column12: gentlemen
column13: I tell you again
column14: with a bleeding heart
column15: I have learnt a great deal this night. I have learnt that it's not only impossible to live a scoundrel
column16: but impossible to die a scoundrel.... No
column17: gentlemen
column18: one must die honest...."""|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: 08:00|"eight o'clock in the morning"|"He bent his head
column2: and hid his face in his hands. The lawyers were silent. A minute later he raised his head and looked at them almost vacantly. His face now expressed complete
column3: hopeless despair
column4: and he sat mute and passive as though hardly conscious of what was happening. In the meantime they had to finish what they were about. They had immediately to begin examining the witnesses. It was by now eight o'clock in the morning. The lights had been extinguished long ago. Mihail Makarovitch and Kalganov
column5: who had been continually in and out of the room all the while the interrogation had been going on
column6: had now both gone out again. The lawyers
column7: too
column8: looked very tired. It was a wretched morning
column9: the whole sky was overcast
column10: and the rain streamed down in bucketfuls. Mitya gazed blankly out of the window."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 11:00|"eleven o'clock"|"It happened that July
column2: during the summer holidays
column3: that the mother and son went to another district
column4: forty-five miles away
column5: to spend a week with a distant relation
column6: whose husband was an official at the railway station (the very station
column7: the nearest one to our town
column8: from which a month later Ivan Fyodorovitch Karamazov set off for Moscow). There Kolya began by carefully investigating every detail connected with the railways
column9: knowing that he could impress his schoolfellows when he got home with his newly acquired knowledge. But there happened to be some other boys in the place with whom he soon made friends. Some of them were living at the station
column10: others in the neighborhood; there were six or seven of them
column11: all between twelve and fifteen
column12: and two of them came from our town. The boys played together
column13: and on the fourth or fifth day of Kolya's stay at the station
column14: a mad bet was made by the foolish boys. Kolya
column15: who was almost the youngest of the party and rather looked down upon by the others in consequence
column16: was moved by vanity or by reckless bravado to bet them two roubles that he would lie down between the rails at night when the eleven o'clock train was due
column17: and would lie there without moving while the train rolled over him at full speed. It is true they made a preliminary investigation
column18: from which it appeared that it was possible to lie so flat between the rails that the train could pass over without touching
column19: but to lie there was no joke! Kolya maintained stoutly that he would. At first they laughed at him
column22: but that only egged him on. What piqued him most was that these boys of fifteen turned up their noses at him too superciliously
column23: and were at first disposed to treat him as ""a small boy
column24: not fit to associate with them
column25: and that was an unendurable insult."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 11:00|eleven|"And so on that frosty
column2: snowy
column3: and windy day in November
column4: Kolya Krassotkin was sitting at home. It was Sunday and there was no school. It had just struck eleven
column5: and he particularly wanted to go out ""on very urgent business
column6: but he was left alone in charge of the house
column7: for it so happened that all its elder inmates were absent owing to a sudden and singular event. Madame Krassotkin had let two little rooms
column8: separated from the rest of the house by a passage
column9: to a doctor's wife with her two small children. This lady was the same age as Anna Fyodorovna
column10: and a great friend of hers. Her husband
column11: the doctor
column12: had taken his departure twelve months before
column13: going first to Orenburg and then to Tashkend
column14: and for the last six months she had not heard a word from him. Had it not been for her friendship with Madame Krassotkin
column15: which was some consolation to the forsaken lady
column16: she would certainly have completely dissolved away in tears. And now
column17: to add to her misfortunes
column20: was suddenly moved the evening before to announce
column22: that she proposed to bring a child into the world before morning. It seemed almost miraculous to every one that no one had noticed the probability of it before. The astounded doctor's wife decided to move Katerina while there was still time to an establishment in the town kept by a midwife for such emergencies. As she set great store by her servant
column23: she promptly carried out this plan and remained there looking after her. By the morning all Madame Krassotkin's friendly sympathy and energy were called upon to render assistance and appeal to some one for help in the case."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 11:00|eleven|"At last it struck eleven and he made up his mind
column2: once for all
column3: that if that ""damned"" Agafya did not come back within ten minutes he should go out without waiting for her
column4: making ""the kids"" promise
column5: of course
column6: to be brave when he was away
column7: not to be naughty
column8: not to cry from fright. With this idea he put on his wadded winter overcoat with its catskin fur collar
column9: slung his satchel round his shoulder
column10: and
column11: regardless of his mother's constantly reiterated entreaties that he would always put on goloshes in such cold weather
column12: he looked at them contemptuously as he crossed the hall and went out with only his boots on. Perezvon
column13: seeing him in his outdoor clothes
column14: began tapping nervously
column15: yet vigorously
column16: on the floor with his tail. Twitching all over
column17: he even uttered a plaintive whine. But Kolya
column19: decided that it was a breach of discipline
column20: kept him for another minute under the bench
column21: and only when he had opened the door into the passage
column22: whistled for him. The dog leapt up like a mad creature and rushed bounding before him rapturously."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 11:30|"half-past eleven"|"In the distance the cathedral clock struck half-past eleven. The boys made haste and they walked as far as Captain Snegiryov's lodging
column2: a considerable distance
column3: quickly and almost in silence. Twenty paces from the house Kolya stopped and told Smurov to go on ahead and ask Karamazov to come out to him."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 06:00|"six o'clock"|"But Ivan made no reply. Alyosha stood under the lamp-post at the cross roads
column2: till Ivan had vanished into the darkness. Then he turned and walked slowly homewards. Both Alyosha and Ivan were living in lodgings; neither of them was willing to live in Fyodor Pavlovitch's empty house. Alyosha had a furnished room in the house of some working people. Ivan lived some distance from him. He had taken a roomy and fairly comfortable lodge attached to a fine house that belonged to a well-to-do lady
column3: the widow of an official. But his only attendant was a deaf and rheumatic old crone who went to bed at six o'clock every evening and got up at six in the morning. Ivan had become remarkably indifferent to his comforts of late
column4: and very fond of being alone. He did everything for himself in the one room he lived in
column5: and rarely entered any of the other rooms in his abode."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: 06:00|"six in the morning"|"But Ivan made no reply. Alyosha stood under the lamp-post at the cross roads
column2: till Ivan had vanished into the darkness. Then he turned and walked slowly homewards. Both Alyosha and Ivan were living in lodgings; neither of them was willing to live in Fyodor Pavlovitch's empty house. Alyosha had a furnished room in the house of some working people. Ivan lived some distance from him. He had taken a roomy and fairly comfortable lodge attached to a fine house that belonged to a well-to-do lady
column3: the widow of an official. But his only attendant was a deaf and rheumatic old crone who went to bed at six o'clock every evening and got up at six in the morning. Ivan had become remarkably indifferent to his comforts of late
column4: and very fond of being alone. He did everything for himself in the one room he lived in
column5: and rarely entered any of the other rooms in his abode."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap < 00:00|"Nearly twelve"|"""Yes
column2: and walked up and down the room an hour ago ... Why have the candles burnt down so? What's the time?""

column1: Nearly twelve.""
No
column2: no
column3: no!"" Ivan cried suddenly. ""It was not a dream. He was here; he was sitting here
column4: on that sofa. When you knocked at the window
column5: I threw a glass at him ... this one. Wait a minute. I was asleep last time
column6: but this dream was not a dream. It has happened before. I have dreams now
column7: Alyosha ... yet they are not dreams
column8: but reality. I walk about
column9: talk and see ... though I am asleep. But he was sitting here
column10: on that sofa there.... He is frightfully stupid
column11: Alyosha
column12: frightfully stupid."" Ivan laughed suddenly and began pacing about the room."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: 10:00|"ten o'clock in the morning"|"At ten o'clock in the morning of the day following the events I have described
column2: the trial of Dmitri Karamazov began in our district court."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 10:00|"ten o'clock"|"At ten o'clock the three judges arrived--the President
column2: one honorary justice of the peace
column3: and one other. The prosecutor
column4: of course
column5: entered immediately after. The President was a short
column6: stout
column7: thick-set man of fifty
column8: with a dyspeptic complexion
column9: dark hair turning gray and cut short
column10: and a red ribbon
column11: of what Order I don't remember. The prosecutor struck me and the others
column12: too
column13: as looking particularly pale
column14: almost green. His face seemed to have grown suddenly thinner
column15: perhaps in a single night
column16: for I had seen him looking as usual only two days before. The President began with asking the court whether all the jury were present."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: ap 08:00|"eight o'clock"|"But I will not detail the evidence of the other witnesses
column2: who only repeated and confirmed what had been said before
column3: though all with their characteristic peculiarities. I repeat
column4: all was brought together in the prosecutor's speech
column5: which I shall quote immediately. Every one was excited
column6: every one was electrified by the late catastrophe
column7: and all were awaiting the speeches for the prosecution and the defense with intense impatience. Fetyukovitch was obviously shaken by Katerina Ivanovna's evidence. But the prosecutor was triumphant. When all the evidence had been taken
column8: the court was adjourned for almost an hour. I believe it was just eight o'clock when the President returned to his seat and our prosecutor
column9: Ippolit Kirillovitch
column10: began his speech."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: < 01:00|"almost one o'clock in the night"|"The jury withdrew and the court adjourned. People could get up
column2: move about
column3: exchange their accumulated impressions
column4: refresh themselves at the buffet. It was very late
column5: almost one o'clock in the night
column6: but nobody went away: the strain was so great that no one could think of repose. All waited with sinking hearts; though that is
column7: perhaps
column8: too much to say
column9: for the ladies were only in a state of hysterical impatience and their hearts were untroubled. An acquittal
column10: they thought
column11: was inevitable. They all prepared themselves for a dramatic moment of general enthusiasm. I must own there were many among the men
column12: too
column13: who were convinced that an acquittal was inevitable. Some were pleased
column14: others frowned
column15: while some were simply dejected
column16: not wanting him to be acquitted. Fetyukovitch himself was confident of his success. He was surrounded by people congratulating him and fawning upon him."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"

column1: 09:00|"nine o'clock in the morning"|"Very early
column2: at nine o'clock in the morning
column3: five days after the trial
column4: Alyosha went to Katerina Ivanovna's to talk over a matter of great importance to both of them
column5: and to give her a message. She sat and talked to him in the very room in which she had once received Grushenka. In the next room Ivan Fyodorovitch lay unconscious in a high fever. Katerina Ivanovna had immediately after the scene at the trial ordered the sick and unconscious man to be carried to her house
column6: disregarding the inevitable gossip and general disapproval of the public. One of the two relations who lived with her had departed to Moscow immediately after the scene in court
column7: the other remained. But if both had gone away
column8: Katerina Ivanovna would have adhered to her resolution
column9: and would have gone on nursing the sick man and sitting by him day and night. Varvinsky and Herzenstube were attending him. The famous doctor had gone back to Moscow
column10: refusing to give an opinion as to the probable end of the illness. Though the doctors encouraged Katerina Ivanovna and Alyosha
column11: it was evident that they could not yet give them positive hopes of recovery."|"The Brothers Karamazov"|"Fyodor Dostoyevsky"
